pullRequest.title: FCCEUD-41
pullRequest.bodyText: Applied editing feedback to sections of the end-user documentation.

nodes.bodyText: Why ProductShortName instead of ProductName in this title?
I actually prefer the shorter, simpler version (do the following)
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2,24 +2,24 @@
 = About {ProductShortName}
 
 {ProductShortName} is a content-management system and publishing platform developed by Red Hat.
-You can use it to publish documents based on AsciiDoc source.
-After adding your modules and assemblies to {ProductShortName}, you can do the following:
+You can use it to publish documents based on AsciiDoc source files.
+After adding your modules and assemblies to {ProductShortName}, you can perform the following actions:

nodes.bodyText:
I wonder if the use of the word "displays" has different connotations in UK English and American English. I see this word a lot in RHV docs, where I prefer the word "appears". "Displays" feels like an active verb to me: I display a painting on the wall, or the browser displays a web page. The painting appears on the wall, the and the web page appears in the browser.
I would say "appears" in this context:
"Preview your content as it appears on the..."
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2,24 +2,24 @@
 = About {ProductShortName}
 
 {ProductShortName} is a content-management system and publishing platform developed by Red Hat.
-You can use it to publish documents based on AsciiDoc source.
-After adding your modules and assemblies to {ProductShortName}, you can do the following:
+You can use it to publish documents based on AsciiDoc source files.
+After adding your modules and assemblies to {ProductShortName}, you can perform the following actions:
 
 . Add metadata
-. Preview your content using the look and feel of the Customer Portal
+. Preview your content as it displays on the Customer Portal

nodes.bodyText: It's OK, but I don't really feel like it adds anything.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2,24 +2,24 @@

 {ProductShortName} is a content-management system and publishing platform developed by Red Hat.
-You can use it to publish documents based on AsciiDoc source.
-After adding your modules and assemblies to {ProductShortName}, you can do the following:
+You can use it to publish documents based on AsciiDoc source files.
+After adding your modules and assemblies to {ProductShortName}, you can perform the following actions:
 
 . Add metadata
-. Preview your content using the look and feel of the Customer Portal
+. Preview your content as it displays on the Customer Portal
 . Associate modules and assemblies with a product
-. Publish, and unpublish content
+. Publish and unpublish your content

nodes.bodyText: Much better, but I would remove the word "now".
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2,24 +2,24 @@
 = About {ProductShortName}
 
 {ProductShortName} is a content-management system and publishing platform developed by Red Hat.
-You can use it to publish documents based on AsciiDoc source.
-After adding your modules and assemblies to {ProductShortName}, you can do the following:
+You can use it to publish documents based on AsciiDoc source files.
+After adding your modules and assemblies to {ProductShortName}, you can perform the following actions:
 
 . Add metadata
-. Preview your content using the look and feel of the Customer Portal
+. Preview your content as it displays on the Customer Portal
 . Associate modules and assemblies with a product
-. Publish, and unpublish content
+. Publish and unpublish your content
 
 The following table describes features that {ProductShortName} does and does not provide.
 
 .{ProductShortName} Features
 |===
 |{ProductShortName} provides: |{ProductShortName} does not provide:
 
-a|* A GUI for managing modules and assemblies, including the ability for authors to search for specific content and other workflow features that are more user-friendly than those currently available.
-* Metadata editing to optimize content for search engines.
-* A module library to enable content reuse.
-* A visual preview of a module so you can see how it will appear on the Customer Portal.
+a|* A Graphical User Interface (GUI) for managing modules and assemblies. You can now search for specific content. {ProductShortName} {ProductNumber} also has better workflow features than {ProductShortName} {ProductNumberPrevious}.

nodes.bodyText:
I think we can use parallel language for all three of these:

Metadata editing, to optimize content for search engines.
Content reuse, to avoid duplicating effort.
A visual preview of a module, to see how content appears to users.

 The following table describes features that {ProductShortName} does and does not provide.
 
 .{ProductShortName} Features
 |===
 |{ProductShortName} provides: |{ProductShortName} does not provide:
 
-a|* A GUI for managing modules and assemblies, including the ability for authors to search for specific content and other workflow features that are more user-friendly than those currently available.
-* Metadata editing to optimize content for search engines.
-* A module library to enable content reuse.
-* A visual preview of a module so you can see how it will appear on the Customer Portal.
+a|* A Graphical User Interface (GUI) for managing modules and assemblies. You can now search for specific content. {ProductShortName} {ProductNumber} also has better workflow features than {ProductShortName} {ProductNumberPrevious}.
+* Metadata editing so that you can optimize content for search engines.
+* A module library that enables content reuse.
+* A visual preview of a module, so that you can see how it displays on the Customer Portal.

nodes.bodyText:
I'm not sure this is still true...at least not as a named feature...I suggest:

Content reuse

nodes.bodyText: I'm fine with "must", but how do you decide on "must" vs "need to"?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2,25 +2,25 @@
 
 = The {ProductShortName} configuration file
 
-You need to create a configuration file, named `pantheon2.yml`, in the root directory of your repository, to enable a Git repository as a source that {ProductShortName} can use to import content. This yaml file provides necessary information that {ProductShortName} uses to interact with files in the repository.
+You must create a configuration file, named `pantheon2.yml`, in the root directory of your repository. You use this file to designate a Git repository as a source that {ProductShortName} can use to import content. This configuration file provides the information necessary for {ProductShortName} to interact with files in the repository.

nodes.bodyText:
One of the first tech writing guidelines I learned was: Don't use "allows", Do use "enables".
"Enables" is more active and sounds more confident and purposeful than "allows".
I'd suggest: enables the following actions:
And if you go with this suggestion, then I think that the actions should start with gerunds (importing, uploading).
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2,25 +2,25 @@
 
 = The {ProductShortName} configuration file
 
-You need to create a configuration file, named `pantheon2.yml`, in the root directory of your repository, to enable a Git repository as a source that {ProductShortName} can use to import content. This yaml file provides necessary information that {ProductShortName} uses to interact with files in the repository.
+You must create a configuration file, named `pantheon2.yml`, in the root directory of your repository. You use this file to designate a Git repository as a source that {ProductShortName} can use to import content. This configuration file provides the information necessary for {ProductShortName} to interact with files in the repository.
 
-The configuration file enables the following:
+The configuration file allows you to perform the following actions:

nodes.bodyText: I think that this was written before we were told that there is no uploader tool anymore. @benradey @emarcusRH ?

nodes.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            A _product_ in {ProductName} is a category that corresponds to an actual product in the Red Hat portfolio. For example: Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) is a Red Hat product. There is also a {ProductName} product named Red Hat Enterprise Linux that contains the modules and assemblies for RHEL documentation.
          
          
            
            A _product_ in {ProductName} is a category that corresponds to an actual product in your organization's portfolio. For example: Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) is a Red Hat product. There is also a {ProductName} product named Red Hat Enterprise Linux that contains the modules and assemblies for RHEL documentation.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1,10 +1,10 @@
 [id='about-products_{context}']
 = About Products in {ProductName}
 
-A _product_ in Pantheon is a category that corresponds to a product in the conventional meaning of the word. For example: Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) is a Red Hat product. There is also a product in {ProductName} named Red Hat Enterprise Linux that contains the modules and assemblies for RHEL documentation.
+A _product_ in {ProductName} is a category that corresponds to an actual product in the Red Hat portfolio. For example: Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) is a Red Hat product. There is also a {ProductName} product named Red Hat Enterprise Linux that contains the modules and assemblies for RHEL documentation.

nodes.bodyText: I do not argue about the correctness of the semi-colon. However, a few years ago, I learned that for a global audience, technical documentation should use Simple English (i.e. English at an approximately 12th grade reading level), and one of the items discussed was abstaining from the use of semi-colons, because they don't add clarity, and can, in fact be confusing, and can easily be replaced by commas or periods.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1,10 +1,10 @@
 [id='about-products_{context}']
 = About Products in {ProductName}
 
-A _product_ in Pantheon is a category that corresponds to a product in the conventional meaning of the word. For example: Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) is a Red Hat product. There is also a product in {ProductName} named Red Hat Enterprise Linux that contains the modules and assemblies for RHEL documentation.
+A _product_ in {ProductName} is a category that corresponds to an actual product in the Red Hat portfolio. For example: Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) is a Red Hat product. There is also a {ProductName} product named Red Hat Enterprise Linux that contains the modules and assemblies for RHEL documentation.
 
 You assign the product name and version in the metadata of a module or assembly. That module or assembly then appears in the search results for that product.
 
 {ProductShortName} does not allow you to add a product name if that name already exists.
 
-The value for the product version can be any string, it is not limited to numbers.
+The value for the product version can be any string; it is not limited to numbers.

nodes.bodyText:
@benradey
I just realized we should add a list of output formats that Pantheon produces...HTML at least. And does Pantheon need to interface with a tranformation tool or does it include that? And does Pantheon publish, or does it feed into a publishing mechanism?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,37 @@
+[id='pantheon_{context}']
+= {ProductShortName}
+
+[role="_abstract"]
+{ProductShortName} is a content-management system and publishing platform developed by Red Hat.
+You can use it to publish documents based on AsciiDoc source files.

commit.message: FCCEUD-41: Applied editing feedback to the end-user documentation.
FCCEUD-41: Added ProductNumberPrevious to the attributes file.
FCCEUD-41: Added abstract tag and updated module name of one module.
FCCEUD-41: Minor updates to incorporate peer review feedback.
FCCEUD-41: Incorporated feedback from peer review.

beforeCommit.message: FCCEUD-41: Incorporated feedback from peer review.

afterCommit.message: FCCEUD-41: Incorporated feedback from peer review.
